column4: If files are copied to /var/cache/apt/archives will they be used before more files are downloaded?
what do you mean used?
shouldn't be too hard. dpkg -i /var/cache/apt/archives/*.deb
- really that easy? - whoa! nice
I assume that would work. That is only in concept though
- np - worth a try. - only takes a couple of minutes to boot the cd again.
- GA-a-k lol! - unresolved dependencies. - it dpkgs alphbetically i guess.
remove the ones you don't want
- How do i use the filter option in synaptic to find them? What happens if Synaptic thinks they are installed and they AREN'T...
not familiar with synaptic, if you want to remove some of the debs, a quick sudo rm whatever.deb will do it via command line
if it thinks it is installed, you can do a sudo apt-get remove whatever to uninstall it
- There are near one HUNDRED packages. - Eep!
if you can find similarities you can use the wildcard, but that is the only way to do it I am pretty sure. If you installed tem all, you are going to have to uninstall and remove them all.
- thats just it. Synaptic shows amny as installed that aren't. - How do i find them?
- isn't Synaptic a facade for apt? Same options, switches, etc, - bruenig - How would the cammand line read to remove those "ghostly" not installed packages?
sudo apt-get remove whatever
- How would i add a wild card to automate test for installation and the removal of nearly one hundred packages?
it is unlikely, but if you know all of the apps that start with a certain thing you want to remove, you could use it to help you out a little bit

- That will thin things down a bit. - still a puzzle isn't it? - Ach! - recycling your saved /var/cache/apt/archive introduces errors and is a bad idea and sadly costly for a great organization like canonical.
if you wanted to keep some of your old debs from /var/cache/apt, why didn't you get those debs and sudo dpkg -i them instead of just copying them into that directory?
right, you should have just sudo dpkg -i them in order to install the ones you wanted. Kind of stupid to just copy them in to the new /var/cache/apt
